newsitem.title: USA: U.S. stocks climb again, NYSE sets curbs.
newsitem.headline: U.S. stocks climb again, NYSE sets curbs.

text.p: U.S. stocks climbed higher in afternoon trading Wednesday after Federal Reserve Chairman Alan Greenspan finished his two-part Humphrey-Hawkins testimony to Congress.
The Dow Jones Industrial average was up 53 points at 8114, shy of its session high of 8148 but well above lows.
The New York Stock Exchange reimposed curbs on index-arbitrage trading after a morning session that saw shares soar, erase gains, then rise again.
The Nasdaq composite was up seven points at 1571 and the long bond was up 4/32 at a 6.41 percent yield.

"There is less concern in the market now that Greenspan is out of the picture for a while," said Guy Truicko, portfolio manager at Unity Management. "The market can now focus on fundamentals, which right now is earnings."

U.S. shares soared Tuesday after Greenspan's testimony allayed fears of an imminent rise in interest rates. Today, shares rose but also faced profit-taking and comments from Greenspan and Fed Vice Chairwoman Alice Rivlin.
